Human: What do you mean too harshly?

Assistant: To be clear, time outs are an effective consequence for misbehavior, but the child may see them as “time-out jail”, which is something to be avoided, rather than a necessary consequence.  So for me to be effective in helping you set up a good consequence for misbehavior, I would need to learn more about your family and what you’re trying to accomplish.

Human: ok so they might be ok once in a while?

Assistant:
chosen:
Yes, I think they can be helpful when the child misbehaves, but they should be used with a little bit of compassion and understanding that it’s not the natural state of things to have an adult yelling at them.  Time outs are also often used without letting the child know how they’re getting out of the time out, which can make it feel arbitrary or like a punishment, rather than a consequence for something they did.  It’s really easy for adults to do this kind of thing unconsciously.  It’s easy to get caught up in the notion that “They’re in time out, and that’s the end of it!” but kids can be pretty imaginative, and they can use their own creativity to make their way out of time outs.  A compassionate time out ends when the child shows a sign of understanding what they’ve done wrong, and are ready to begin again.  That way the child knows they’re learning, and that the parent is seeing them as an intelligent person, even if they sometimes mess up.  You can still use the other techniques you were using to be tough when necessary, but using a compassionate approach will let you use them without actually using them!

prompt:
Human: Why are so many stores closed on Sundays? Is it a religious reason?

Assistant:
chosen: No.  The USA was founded by a Puritan group of Protestants, but it didn’t adopt the religion of the Puritans until much later, and it was always a secular state.  The Puritans observed the Sabbath on Sunday, and the Puritans only had a small influence in the early history of the USA.  It’s difficult to trace the origins of closing stores on Sunday, but one early and short-lived attempt at forcing the Sabbath on people in the 1800s was motivated by the Protestant ideal that people should spend Sunday focusing on spiritual activities.  By the mid-1800s, when the Sunday closing law was made, there was not a lot of pressure from that standpoint, but the church had begun to advocate for Sunday closing laws as a way of counteracting the negative effects of industrialization on the day of rest.  Even after that shift, closing stores on Sunday was not always possible, since the religious Sunday was not always chosen for observance.  And as industrialization accelerated and mechanization made it possible to operate stores on Sunday, the law was not enforced as much as people liked.  The day of rest was also being violated by stores that stayed open all day on Sunday, so closing stores on Sundays became an effort to protect the Sabbath for all citizens.

prompt:
Human: If you were to float above the ground would the Earth rotate below you?

Assistant:
chosen:
That is a common question I’m asked, and I think it has a tricky answer!  I think my answer is “yes” and “no.”  You may be thinking of “Time Dilation” or “Warp Drive”, but it’s not what I’m thinking of.   What I’m thinking of is the way that our imagination works.

Imagine you had a thin sheet of flexible plastic which could be pulled out from a roll to become a long tube, about 100m long.  We call this a “wormhole”, as in, it’s a flexible wormhole.  If you were floating in space, and grabbed one end of it and held it, then the other end would stretch to the ground, into the ground and back out again.  If you stood on the ground, you could then pull it and have it lift you up into the air.  The question is, could the Earth rotate under the “wormhole” while the person holding it was “in the air”?

The answer is, no.  The “wormhole” analogy is a bit strange, so let me explain it more carefully.

I think when you are floating above the ground, you are also moving around it.  But in the same way that you can hold one end of the wormhole while floating, the Earth is also moving around you.  So you might wonder how it could “rotate” while you are also moving around it.

This is a situation of accelerating motion.  A spaceship, say, accelerates around the Earth so that it is moving at a speed which is near the speed of light.  As it flies past, we say it moves “faster than light” and we call this “tachyonic motion” or “tachyons” for short.  Tachyons are things that accelerate faster than light, and as they pass by, objects may seem to move or “rotate” as they pass, even though the objects themselves are not moving.

I hope this answer has helped to clarify how we can still see the Earth rotating even if it is also accelerating in the other direction.  The Earth is accelerating around you, which is what makes you feel weightless.  This is why it’s called “Weightlessness”.

Human: Got it, but can you please identify the four lunar phases of the moon?

Assistant:
chosen:
Yes. The phases of the moon refer to how much the moon is illuminated by the sun:

- New Moon - The moon is completely in shadow, and therefore completely dark in the night sky.  You cannot see any portion of the moon because it is completely dark.

- Waxing Crescent - The moon has started to move out of shadow and you can see a small portion of it in the night sky.  This is the first visible phase of the moon.

- Waxing Gibbous - You can see the entire upper half of the moon in the sky.  This is halfway between a crescent and a full moon.

- Full Moon - The moon is completely illuminated by the sun.  This is the brightest phase of the moon.

- Waning Gibbous - You can see the entire lower half of the moon in the sky.  This is halfway between the full moon and a crescent.

- Waning Crescent - You can see less and less of the moon as it disappears back into shadow.  This is the final visible phase of the moon.

Human: Can you describe how an autonomous car works?

Assistant:
chosen:
One way to think about it is this:  You can make a car without a human driver in two different ways.  The first is to put a robot in the car, which is kind of like a remote-control helicopter.  The robot would have a video camera, some artificial intelligence, and some sensors.  When you are driving, you would be able to see out the window and steer and accelerate and brake with a joystick or other controls, so it’s like you are driving, but you aren’t.  You’d control the robot, and the robot would control the car.  If you wanted to be super safe, you could build an extra sensor in the car that would only drive in the safest conditions, and when there were hazards, or if the car sensed the driver wasn’t doing what they should, then the robot would actually take over control of the car and drive it instead.  This is the safer way, but it would also be kind of slow because the robot would just be doing the exact same thing that you would have done, and if you messed up, the robot would also mess up.

The other way is to give your car a super powerful computer, with artificial intelligence, and a pretty fast internet connection, and let it drive itself.  This car would also have some sensors, but it wouldn’t really need them, because it would always have access to so much more information than you do.  When you are driving, you would choose where you want to go, and your car would use all of its data to come up with the best route and way to get there.  The computer would make all the decisions about how to handle unexpected events and road conditions, and would do the braking and steering and everything.  It’s kind of like having a flying car that is in control of everything, and you just decide where you want to go.  Most people use cars like this, because they’re pretty good and most of the time you don’t really want to do all of that work and risking making a mistake.

prompt:
Human: I like to host guests at my home from time to time, and I am gathering  recipes of different dishes and drinks to keep things interesting. I am interested in trying some Pakistani dishes. Can you give me a recipe for Aloo Ki Tikki?

Assistant:
chosen:
Sure, Aloo ki Tikki (recipe below). I recommend buying all the ingredients ahead of time. Then you will need to start with step two and have everything chopped and ready by the time you get to step four.

1 onion, finely chopped (5 tablespoons)

5 potatoes (red skinned if possible, they have a sweet taste), cubed

2-3 tomatoes, finely chopped (6-8 tbsp)

1 tsp ginger, grated

1 tsp salt

2-3 cloves of garlic, crushed

1⁄2 tsp red chili powder

2-3 tbsp cumin powder

1 tbsp coriander powder

1 tbsp garam masala

2 tbsp lemon juice

1⁄2 cup (2 oz) coriander, chopped (optional)

Cooking oil

----

Heat cooking oil in a deep pan or kadhai, add the onion, and fry it until it turns light golden.

Remove the onions and drain on a paper towel. Leave the oil in the pan.

Add the tomatoes, ginger, garlic, and salt, stir and cook for about 3 minutes.

Add the chili powder, cumin, coriander, and garam masala. Stir well, and cook for 2 minutes.

Add the potatoes, and cook for 2 minutes.

Turn the heat down, and mix well. Add 2-3 tbsp water, and cook for 8-10 minutes. Keep stirring and checking.

Add the lemon juice. Remove from heat. Mix in the coriander and let it cool a little.

Cut potatoes and tomato and shape into balls.

Heat some cooking oil in a deep pan or kadhai. When the oil is hot, add the potatoes. Fry till they turn light golden brown.

In a paper towel, drain the fried potatoes. Leave the oil in the pan.

In the same oil, add the onion, tomatoes, and fried potatoes.

Stir well, and add 2-3 tbsp water. Cook for 3-4 minutes.

----
